awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Longitudinal Study of Knowledge Diffusion and Societal Impact of Nanomanufacturing Research & Development: Harnessing Data for Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the National Nanotechnology Initiative was implemented in 2000, significant progress has been made in understanding the unique physical phenomena that occur at the nano-scale and in designing and fabricating new nano-scale materials, structures, devices and systems. To realize the benefits to the nation of these advances in nanotechnology, however, advances must also be made in nanomanufacturing, and these advances must translate, in turn, into production by industry.  This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will investigate the knowledge diffusion and societal impact of nanomanufacturing research, using advanced data analytics frameworks. The study results are expected to inform government, industry, and researchers in identifying research gaps and how resources and investments could be directed to address obstacles to scaling the most promising nanotechnology discovery to industrial production. The project is highly exploratory and hence suitable for the EAGER program. The research results will be broadly distributed. The project responds to the NSF Big Idea--Harnessing Data for 21st Century Science and Engineering.

This project develops new analytical models and frameworks to study and analyze the outputs of research in nanomanufacturing. Nanotechnology studies are mostly high-level industry-wide reviews based on smaller-scale survey and are mostly available to members. This project is data science-driven, based on existing large databases and state-of-the-art data analytics including journal articles, patents, licenses and technology transfer datasets and made publicly available. The project develops a framework that systematically collects relevant data generated in the past 15-20 years from university technology transfer offices, public news databases, patents and publications, and analyzes the influence of research investments and specific projects on knowledge diffusion and its commercial impact. From the data, the project develops a novel, scalable text mining, topic modeling, trend analysis, and network analysis to quantify, evaluate, and visualize each research effort's long-term knowledge diffusion. The expected outcomes are to understand, (1) nanomanufacturing knowledge diffusion path from academic publications to patents to commercialization, (2) impact of federal investment in nanomanufacturing research in facilitating long-term knowledge diffusion, and (3) the difference between large-scale collaborative projects and small-scale individual projects facilitating long-term knowledge diffusion. The broad set of analytical techniques developed from this research are expected to further advance the scientific use of these methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report

This project aimed to leverage a data-driven approach to understand the knowledge diffusion and societal impact of nanomanufacturing research and development (R&D). We conducted three streams of research within the project.

The first research stream continuously monitored and analyzed global nanotechnology development trends between 2010 and 2020 (the ?Nano2? stage). We collected NSF nanoscience and engineering (NSE) awards, scientific papers, and patent publications to compare major international nanotechnology R&D leaders? performance.

Since 2010, NSF granted approximately 13-14% of awards annually to NSE research. The increase of government funding on NSE research has resulted in a steady growth of NSE R&D. US institutions led the publication of high-quality NSE papers in high-impact journals such as Nature and Science, and US NSE papers published in International Scientific Indexing journals increased by 1,638 annually. US-originated patent awards worldwide witnessed similar steady growth. Compared with the steady growth in the US, published papers and granted patents have shown a sharp increase in China after 2012. This sharp increase can be attributed to the policy-driven investments in nanotechnology-related fields. These different trends motivated us to compare and contrast the US and China?s nanotechnology R&D knowledge dissemination and market characteristics.

In our second research stream, we conducted a nanotechnology landscape analysis between the US and China to compare their nanotechnology markets from 2001 to 2017. Specifically, we examined the knowledge diffusion path from academic publications to patents in nanotechnology, and several critical differences were found.

(1) Worldwide patent recognition. 83.44% of United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) nanotechnology patent applicants applied for the same inventions in two or more countries. These applicants likely attached great importance to international markets. In contrast, 81.7% of patent applicants in China are filed only within the China National Intellectual Property Administration (CNIPA), focusing on the domestic market and resulting in less recognition worldwide.

(2) Technology fields and R&D focuses. We mapped patents to 35 fields based on the World Intellectual Property Organization?s International Plumbing Code (e.g., semiconductors, biotechnology) and identified 13 topics (i.e., R&D focuses) for both US and China markets. The technology fields with the most granted patents in the US are semiconductors and electrical machinery, which are product-oriented. In contrast, the most granted fields in the CNIPA are materials, metallurgy, and chemistry/chemical engineering, and these fields are heavily manufacturing-oriented. Our topic evolution analysis also found that the US market primarily focused on nanoelectronics and nanomedicine, while China focused on nanomaterials.

(3) R&D knowledge dissemination patterns. We conducted a collaboration network analysis on patent assignees. We found a high network density in the US market, indicating wide, extensive collaborations among assignees. In contrast, we observed a hierarchical, tree-like collaboration structure in China?s market, where small institutes or companies dedicatedly collaborate with a specific major organization, forming clusters that are less collaborative within the market. In the USPTO, 25.23% of collaborations are international, significantly higher than that of the CNIPA (9.93%). The dominant collaboration types are within-industry (58.77%) in the USPTO and academia-industry (40.64%) in the CNIPA.

In addition to these findings, our nanotechnology landscape analysis framework can be generalized to other technology domains or disciplines to conduct systematic, in-depth, data-driven market analysis.

In our third research stream, we conducted an exploratory study to understand NSF nanotechnology funding?s impact on universities? commercialization success during Nano 2. We proposed a novel research framework for directly assessing the impact of NSF nanotechnology funding using the monetary value extracted from university news. 100 higher-funded universities and 10 lower-funded universities by NSF NSE awards were analyzed.

Among higher-funded universities, MIT has the most coverage in nanotechnology news (806), followed by UW Madison (560). In general, higher-funded universities such as UMich, MIT, UW Madison, and UT Austin disclosed over 100 commercialization news items. Most lower-funded universities have fewer than ten commercialization news items. Among the higher-funded universities, Cornell University was the most funded university by NSF as well as the most successful one in terms of nanotechnology commercialization, with $1 billion in outcomes. Though as a lower-funded university, the New York Institute of Technology achieved nanotechnology commercialization outcomes worth $40 million.

We found a strong positive correlation between the NSF award amount and a university?s commercialization value. On average, $1 million in NSF funding leads to nanotechnology commercialization outcomes valued at $2.51 million. However, at the end of Nano 2, most universities are still in their initial commercialization stages, irrespective of the received NSF funding amount. These universities can learn from two successful commercialization cases (Pacific Biosciences and Crossbar, Inc.). Their success was strongly supported by NSF fundings that enabled continuous R&D to form the foundation for commercialization. Second, once the first critical R&D outcome (e.g., scientific paper) was generated, there was a 6 to 7 years period before releasing the first commercial product.

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2021
Modified by: Hsinchun Chen
